questions.text:
A synapse is a junction between _______.
  1. Axon and dendrite
  2. Axon and axon
  3. Axon and muscle cell
  4. Axon and soma
questions.solution:
Impulses are transmitted from one nerve cell to another cell at junctions called synapse. These are the junctions where the axon or some other portion of one cell (the presynaptic cell) terminates on the dendrites, soma, or axon of another neuron or, in some cases, a muscle or gland cell (the postsynaptic cell).

There are two major types of synapses:

  • Chemical 
  • Electrical

When a neuron terminates on a muscle , it is called a neuromuscular junction . This is an example of a chemical synapse .

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding chemical synapses except_____

choices.text: These are the most common type of synapses
Neurotransmitter is produced by the presynaptic neuron
Protoplasmic continuity between pre- and post- synaptic membrane ensures faster conduction

questions.solution:
Chemical synapses are interneuronal junctions without protoplasmic continuity. 

Most of the synapses used for signal transmission in the central nervous system of the human being are chemical synapses.

In these synapses, the first neuron (presynaptic neuron) secretes neurotransmitters at its nerve ending synapse. This transmitter, in turn, acts on receptor proteins in the membrane of the next neuron (post-synaptic neuron) to excite the neuron, inhibit it, or modify its sensitivity in some other way. 

As neurotransmitters are released only by the pre-synaptic neuron, the synaptic conduction in the CNS is only orthodromic (unidirectional).

Related Pearl: Differences between Chemical and Electrical Synapses

Synaptic delay

Significant: atleast 0.3 ms, usually 1-5 ms or longer

Virtually absent

Direction of transmission

Unidirectional

Usually bidirectional

questions.text: In a typical chemical synaptic cleft, the extracellular distance between the presynaptic plasma membrane and the postsynaptic plasma membrane is approximately_____
questions.solution:
In a typical chemical synaptic cleft, the extracellular distance between the presynaptic plasma membrane and the postsynaptic plasma membrane is approximately 20-40nm.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding neurotransmitters?

choices.text: All neurotransmitter are derived from amino acids
Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter in the CNS
They do not act on ionotropic receptors
They are released on repolarization of the nerve

questions.solution:
Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter in the CNS.

Neurotransmitters are the substances that mediate chemical signaling between neurons. They can be choline esters, biogenic amines, amino acids, and neuropeptides.

Two main classes of chemical substances that serve as neurotransmitters:

  • small-molecule neurotransmitter (acetylcholine)
  • large molecule neurotransmitter (enkephalin)

They can act on ionotropic receptors (ligand-gated ion channels) and/or metabotropic receptors on the postsynaptic membrane to produce a change in membrane potential to bring about their action.

Criteria for the substance to be neurotransmitter:

  • the substance must be demonstrated to be present in the presynaptic terminal.
  • the cell must be able to synthesize the substance.
  • should be released on depolarization of the terminal.
  • there should be specific receptors for it on the postsynaptic membrane.
  • if the substance is applied exogenously to the postsynaptic membrane at physiologic concentration, the response of the postsynaptic cell must mimic the in vivo response.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a monoamine neurotransmitter?
questions.solution:
GABA is not a monoamine neurotransmitter. It is an amino acid.

Biogenic amines are small, charged molecules that are synthesized from amino acids and contain an amino group (R—NH2). Amines known to act as neurotransmitters are dopamine, norepinephrine (noradrenaline), epinephrine (adrenaline), serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine [5-HT]).

Amino acids and their derived amines acting as neurotransmitters:

  • Tyrosine -  catecholamines : dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine .
  • Tryptophan - serotonin
  • Histidine - histamine

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding metabotropic neurotransmitters?

choices.text: They act through second messenger systems
They bind to cationic channels and increase influx of Na
They bind to anionic channels and increase influx of Cl
They inhibit the fusion of synaptic vesicle with the synaptic cleft

questions.solution:
Neurotransmitter receptors that act through second messenger systems are called metabotropic receptors.

Neurotransmitters bind to receptors on the post-synaptic membrane to activate ion channels in one of the two ways:

  • by gating ion channels directly (ionotropic receptors).
  • by activating a second messenger (metabotropic receptor) for a prolonged postsynaptic neu­ronal excitation or inhibition. Most commonly activated is a G-protein coupled membrane receptor.

The following four changes can occur usually after binding to a G-protein coupled receptor:

  • Opening specific ion channels through the post-synaptic cell membrane.
  • Activation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) or cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) in the neuronal cell.
  • Activation of one or more intracellular enzymes. 
  • Activation of gene transcription. Activation of gene transcription is one of the most important effects of activation of the second messenger systems because gene transcription can cause formation of new proteins within the neuron, thereby changing its metabolic machinery or its structure.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the neurotransmitter glutamate in the brain?

choices.text: It is involved in excitatory neurotansmission
It is a minor neurotransmitter in the brain
It acts via both ionotropic and metabotropic receptors
Glycine binding to the NMDA receptor is essential for the receptor to respond to glutamate

questions.solution:
Glutamate is a major excitatory neurotransmitter responsible for ~75% excitatory neurotransmission in the CNS.

Glutamate is the best-known example of excitatory amino acid neurotransmitters. It brings about its action via both ionotropic and metabotropic receptors.

 Glutamate Receptors :

Type

Mechanism of Action

Ionotropic Glutamate Receptors

AMPA, Kainate receptors

Primarily permits influx of Na+ and efflux of K+ →EPSP (excitatory postsynaptic potential)

NMDA receptors

Permits ↑ influx of Ca2+ along with Na+ 

→EPSP (excitatory postsynaptic potential)

(Glycine binding to the NMDA receptor is essential for the receptor to respond to glutamate)

Metabotropic Glutamate Receptor(mGluR)

Leads to either ↑ in IP3/DAG or ↓cAMP

 

 

Related Pearl: Neurotransmitters and Type of Receptor

questions.text: Which of the following is a well-known inhibitory brain neurotransmitter?
questions.solution:
GABA (gamma-amino-butyric acid) is probably the best known inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain, especially in the forebrain regions.

GABA mediates both presynaptic and postsynaptic inhibition

GABA Receptors :

Type

Mechanism of Action

GABA A and GABA C

Ionotropic receptors

Activation →↑Cl- influx into the neurons → IPSP (inhibitory postsynaptic potential)

Benzodiazepines (diazepam), barbiturates and phenobarbital enhance/potentiate the effect of GABA A receptors (neuromodulation)

GABA B

Metabotropic receptors

G-protein coupled receptors

Gi→inhibits adenylyl cyclase to open K+ channels 

G0→ inhibits or delays Ca2+ influx

Net effect=IPSP

Other options :

  • Glutamate is a good example of an excitatory brain neurotransmitter.
  • Acetylcholine and glycine have been known to play either excitatory or inhibitory neurotransmitter roles depending on the particular brain circuits under study.

Note:

Glycine sometimes potentiates the excitatory action of glutamate at NMDA receptors. So, it might act as an excitatory neurotransmitter as well.

Related Pearl: Neurotransmitters and Type of Receptor

Ligand-gated (GABA A and GABA C)

GPCR (GABA B)

Acetylcholine

Nicotinic – Ligand

GPCR

GPCR (except 5HT3 which is ligand gated)

questions.solution:
GABA A is an ionotropic receptor.

GABA is the major inhibitory mediator both pre and postsynaptically in the brain.

Benzodiazepines (eg. Diazepam), barbiturates and phenobarbital enhance/potentiate the effect of GABA A receptors (neuromodulation)

GABA B

Gi→inhibits adenylyl cyclase to open K+ channels G

G0→ inhibits or delays Ca2+ influx

Net effect=IPSP

questions.text: Which is not true about neuromodulators?

choices.text: Modify the postsynaptic neuron’s response to a specific neurotransmitter
May change the presynaptic neuron’s release of a transmitter
May be released by the presynaptic neuron along with the neurotransmitter

questions.solution:
Neuromodulators typically have actions that are slower than neurotransmitters.

Neuromodulators are chemicals released by neurons that have little or no direct effects on their own but can modify the effects of neurotransmitters.

They can modify the postsynaptic neuron’s response to a neurotransmitter and they can change how much of a neurotransmitter the presynaptic neuron synthesizes or releases.

Neuromodulators also can be released by the presynaptic neuron along with the neurotransmitter.

questions.text: A medical student was doing research in a laboratory that studies the neuromuscular junction. Which of the following events at the junction are listed in correct sequential order?

choices.text: Motor neuron action potential, acetylcholine release, Ca2+ entry at the endplate
Ca2+ entry into the motor nerve terminal, acetylcholine release, Na+ entry at the endplate
Ca2+ entry into the motor nerve terminal, Na+ entry at the endplate, motor neuron action potential
Na+ entry at the endplate, acetylcholine release, muscle fiber action potential

questions.solution:
Events Occurring at the Chemical Synapse:

The action potential arriving at the end of the motor neuron increases the permeability of its endings to Ca2+

                                                                        ↓

Ca2+ enters the endings and triggers a marked increase in exocytosis of the acetylcholine-containing synaptic vesicles

                                                                        ↓

Binding of acetylcholine to nicotinic receptors increases the Na+ and K+ conductance

                                                                        ↓

Resultant influx of Na+ produces a local depolarizing potential, the endplate potential

                                                                        ↓

The current created by this local potential depolarizes the adjacent muscle membrane to its firing level

                                                                        ↓

Action potentials are generated on either side of the endplate and are conducted away from the endplate in both directions along the muscle fiber. This muscle action potential, in turn, initiates muscle contraction.

Acetylcholine is then removed from the synaptic cleft by acetylcholinesterase, which is present in high concentration at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: Excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) is due to the influx of ______.
questions.solution:
Excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) is due to the influx of sodium ions (Na+).

At the post-synaptic membrane, neurotransmitters binding to receptors generate responses that can be excitatory or inhibitory. If it generates an excitatory response (makes the membrane more electrically positive/ depolarized), it is an excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) because it makes the cell more likely to reach an action potential.

EPSP may be due to

  • The opening of sodium channels or calcium channels to allow large numbers of positive electrical charges to flow to the interior of the postsynaptic cell.
  • Depressed conduction through chloride or potassium channels or both.
  • Various changes in the internal metabolism of the postsynaptic neuron to increase the number of excitatory membrane receptors or decrease the number of inhibitory membrane receptors.

As seen in the figure, following the discharge of the sensory neuron, there is positivity in the motor neuron signifying a EPSP.

questions.text: Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential (IPSP) is due to influx of ______
questions.solution:
Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential (IPSP) is due to the influx of chloride ions (Cl-).

If, binding of a neurotransmitter causes the postsynaptic membrane to become more negative (hyperpolarized), it is called an inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) because hyperpolarization moves the membrane potential farther from the threshold and makes the cell less likely to reach an action potential.

IPSP may be due to :

  • Increase in Cl- influx. This action causes diffusion of negatively charged chloride ions from outside the postsynaptic neuron to the inside, thereby carrying negative charges inward and increasing the negativity inside. This leads to hyperpolarization.
  • Increase in K+ efflux. This action causes positive ions to diffuse to the exterior, which causes increased negativity inside the neuron, which leads to hyperpolarization.
  • Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors or decrease the number of excitatory receptors.

questions.text: The following effect in the motor neuron is due to:

choices.text: Opening of chloride ion channels through the pre-synaptic neuronal membrane
Increase in conductance of potassium ions to the inside of the neuron
Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors
Increase in conductance of sodium ions inside the neuron

questions.solution:
Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors can cause the effect shown, namely, the generation of IPSP.

In the figure given, there is an increased negativity in the motor neuron following the action potential in the interneuron. So, the synaptic potential is IPSP. This can be caused at the postsynaptic membrane due to Cl- influx, K+ efflux or activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors or decrease the number of excitatory receptors.

Other options:

  • Opening of chloride ion channels through the post-synaptic neuronal membrane. 
  • Increase in conductance of potassium ions to the outside of the postsynaptic neuron.
  • Increase in conductance of sodium ions inside the neuron causes the generation of an EPSP.

Related Pearl: Comparison between EPSP vs IPSP

EPSP IPSP
EPSP is an electrical charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of excitatory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane more likely to generate an action potential. IPSP is an electric charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of inhibitory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane less likely to generate an action potential.
EPSP is caused by Influx of Na+ or Ca2+ ions IPSP is caused by Influx of Cl- ions mainly (also by efflux of K+ ions)
Results in depolarization of membrane Results in hyperpolarization of membrane
Increases the firing rate of action potential on postsynaptic membrane Decreases the firing rate of action potential on post synaptic membrane
Neurotransmitters involved – Glutamate, Aspartate Neurotransmitters involved – Glycine, GABA

 

EPSP- Excitatory PostSynaptic Potentials

IPSP- Inhibitory PostSynaptic Potentials

questions.text: Slow inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) is generated by all except _______
questions.solution:
Slow EPSPs and IPSPs are not generated by skeletal muscles.

Slow excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSPs) are seen in autonomic ganglia, cardiac, and smooth muscle, and cortical neurons.

EPSPs and IPSPs occur after a latency of 0.5ms while slow EPSPs and IPSPs occur after a latency of 100–500 ms and last for several seconds. The slow EPSPs are due to a decrease in K+ efflux, and the slow IPSPs are due to an increase in K+ efflux.

questions.text: Which of the following physiologic processes is not correctly matched?

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition: GABA-B receptors decrease K+ conductance.
Presynaptic inhibition: GABA-A receptors increase Cl– conductance.

questions.solution:
GABA-B receptors are present in the spinal cord and appear to mediate presynaptic inhibition via a G-protein that produces an increase in K+ conductance. 

PRE-SYNAPTIC INHIBITION

  • Presynaptic inhibition is a process mediated by neurons whose terminals are on excitatory endings, forming axoaxonal synapses.
  • The first transmitter shown to produce presynaptic inhibition was GABA. On the pre-synaptic membrane
    • Acting via GABA-A receptors, GABA increases Cl– conductance. 
    • GABA-B receptors appear to mediate presynaptic inhibition via a G-protein that produces an increase in K+ conductance. 
  • This leads to hyperpolarization of the pre-synaptic membrane and inhibition of release of the neurotransmittor from the pre-synaptic neuron.
 

POST-SYNAPTIC INHIBITION

  • Postsynaptic inhibition occurs when an inhibitory transmitter such as glycine or GABA is released from a presynaptic nerve terminal onto the postsynaptic neuron to induce an IPSP in the postsynaptic neuron.
  • In the figure shown below, an inhibitory transmitter such as GABA is released from the nerve terminals of an inhibitory interneuron (dark) that synapses on a postsynaptic neuron.

questions.text: Renshaw cell inhibition is ________
questions.solution:
Renshaw cell inhibition is an example of feedback inhibition.

The axon of a spinal motor neuron has a recurrent collateral that synapses on an inhibitory interneuron that terminates on the cell body of the same and other motor neurons. The inhibitory interneuron is called a Renshaw cell and its neurotransmitter is glycine.

questions.text: Feedforward inhibition is seen in ________
questions.solution:
Feedforward inhibition is seen in the cerebellum. In the cerebellum, stimulation of basket cells / stellate cells produces IPSPs in the Purkinje cells (i.e, inhibits Purkinje cells)

In feedforward inhibition, a presynaptic cell excites an inhibitory interneuron which then inhibits the next follower cell.

In cerebellum (Refer flow chart):

This arrangement is called feed-forward inhibition which presumably limits the duration of excitation produced by any given afferent volley.

Note: Renshaw cell carries out the negative feedback inhibition of a spinal motor neuron.

questions.text: Presynaptic facilitation is due to prolonged opening of_____
questions.solution:
Presynaptic facilitation is due to prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels .

In presynaptic facilitation, the serotonin released at the axoaxonal ending increases the intraneuronal cAMP levels→ phosphorylation and consequent closure of K+ channels → slowing of repolarization and prolonging the depolarization by prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

questions.text: A person with myasthenia gravis notes increased muscle strength when he is treated with an acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor.  The basis for his improvement is due to the increase in _______

choices.text: The amount of acetylcholine (ACh) released from motor nerves
The level of ACh at the muscle end plates
The number of ACh receptors on the motor end plates
Synthesis of norepinephrine in motor nerves

questions.solution:
Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate.

Myasthenia gravis:

  • It is caused by the presence of antibodies to the ACh receptor.
  • Is characterized by skeletal muscle weakness and fatigability resulting from a reduced number of ACh receptors on the muscle end plate.
  • The size of the EPP (end plate potential) is reduced.
  • Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate, partially compensating for the reduced number of receptors.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman had an autonomic neuropathy that disrupted the sympathetic nerve supply to the pupillary dilator muscle of her right eye. While having her eyes examined, the ophthalmologist placed a sympathomimetic drug in both her eyes. The right eye became much more dilated than the left  eye. This suggests that:

choices.text: The sympathetic nerve to the right eye had regenerated
The parasympathetic nerve supply to the right eye remained intact and compensated for the loss of the sympathetic nerve
The left eye also had nerve damage and so was not responding as expected

questions.solution:
Denervation supersensitivity develops in the muscle after the nerve supplying it is cut. Since the nerve to her right dilator pupillae is damaged, the right eye becomes excessively sensitive to the sympathomimetic drug. So, the right eye becomes much more dilated than the left.

Denervation Supersensitivity:

  • When the motor nerve to skeletal muscle is degenerated, the muscle gradually becomes extremely sensitive to acetylcholine. This is called denervation hypersensitivity or supersensitivity.
  • Normally nicotinic receptors are located only in the vicinity of the motor endplate where the axon of the motor nerve terminates. When the motor nerve is severed, there is a marked proliferation of nicotinic receptors over a wide region of the neuromuscular junction.
  • Denervation supersensitivity also occurs at autonomic junctions. Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not atrophy when denervated, but it becomes hyperresponsive to the chemical mediator that normally activates it.
  • This hyperresponsiveness can be demonstrated by using pharmacologic tools rather than actual nerve section. Prolonged use of a drug such as reserpine can be used to deplete transmitter stores and prevent the target organ from being exposed to norepinephrine for an extended period. Once the drug usage is stopped, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle will be supersensitive to subsequent release of the neurotransmitter.

Option a) If the symapthetic nerve would have regenerated, both right and left eye would have been equally sensitive to the drug and so, would have dilated equally.

Option b) Parasympathetic nerves supply the spinchter pupillae muscle. So, if stimulated they would constrict the eye not dilate it. Also, the drug added was a sympathomimetic agent. So, parasympathetic nerves are not stimulated in the first place

Option d) If the left eye was damaged, it would also have denervation supersensitivity. Again, both eyes would dilate equally, but more than that of normal.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about neurotransmitters?

choices.text: They must be present at the pre-synaptic membrane
Neurons must be able to synthesize the substance
They are released on repolarization of the nerve
Specific receptors must be present on the post-synaptic membrane

questions.solution:
Neurotransmitters should be released on depolarization of the terminal.

  • Neurotransmitters are the substances that mediate chemical signaling between neurons.
  • The transmission of information at chemical synapses involves the release of neurotransmitter from a presynaptic cell, diffusion across the synaptic cleft, and binding of the neurotransmitter to specific receptors on the postsynaptic membrane to produce a change in membrane potential.

Criteria for the substance to be neurotransmitter

  • the substance must be demonstrated to be present in the presynaptic terminal
  • the cell must be able to synthesize the substance.
  • should be released on depolarization of the terminal.
  • there should be specific receptors for it on the postsynaptic membrane.
  • if the substance is applied exogenously to the postsynaptic membrane at physiologic concentration, the response of the postsynaptic cell must mimic the in vivo response

questions.text: Neurotransmitter can be degraded by all except_____

choices.text: Can diffuse out of synaptic cleft

questions.solution:
The final steps in the process lead to termination of the actions of the neurotransmitter and include

  • Reuptake into the nerve terminal or glial cell
  • Enzymatic degradation.
  • Diffusion away from the synaptic cleft

questions.text: Which of the following endogenous opioids is correctly matched with the receptor at which it has maximum potency?
questions.solution:
Enkephalins have maximum potency at δ receptors.

Dynorphins have maximum potency at κ receptors.

Endorphins have maximum potency at μ receptors.

Note: There is a difference of opinion among Goodman & Gillman's textbook and Ganong’s review of medical physiology(26th edition pg 151). According to Goodman & Gillman's textbook above answer is correct.

Related Pearl: Opioid Receptors

Receptor

Effect

μ

Miosis

Urine retention

Sedation

Slowed GI transit - constipation

Supraspinal and spinal analgesia

Respiratory depression

Muscular rigidity

Euphoria 

Modulation of hormone and neurotransmitter release

δ

Supraspinal and spinal analgesia 

Modulation of hormone
and neurotransmitter release

κ

Slowed GI transit - constipation

Supraspinal and spinal analgesia

Psychotomimetic effect- Dysphoria

questions.text: Which of the following physiologic processes is not correctly paired with a structure?

choices.text: Synaptic vesicle docking and fusion : presynaptic nerve terminal

questions.solution:
Endplate potential is generated via nicotinic cholinergic receptor.

The acetylcholine released from the motor neuron diffuses to nicotinic cholinergic (NM) receptors that are concentrated at the tops of the junctional folds of the membrane of the motor endplate.

questions.text: Which of the following electrophysiologic events is correctly paired with the change in ionic currents causing the event?

choices.text: Fast inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (IPSPs) and closing of Cl– channels
Fast excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) and an decrease in Ca2+ conductance
Endplate potential and an increase in Na+ conductance
Presynaptic inhibition and closure of voltage-gated K+ channels

questions.solution:
Binding of acetylcholine to neuromuscular junction receptors increases the Na+ and K+ conductance, and the resultant influx of Na+ produces a depolarizing potential, the endplate potential.

IPSP may be due to

  • Opening of chloride ion channels through the postsynaptic neuronal membrane
  • Increase in conductance of potassium ions out of the neuron.
  • Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors or decrease the number of excitatory receptors.

EPSP may be due to

  • The opening of sodium channels to allow large numbers of positive electrical charges to flow to the interior of the postsynaptic cell.
  • Depressed conduction through chloride or potassium channels, or both.
  • Various changes in the internal metabolism of the postsynaptic neuron to increase the number of excitatory membrane receptors or decrease the number of inhibitory membrane receptors.

questions.text: How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse?

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane
Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.solution:
In electrical synapses, the cytoplasm of adjacent cells is directly connected by gap junctions (connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next cell.

The transmis­sion in electrical synapses is bidirectional and there is no synaptic delay. Unlike chemical synapses, electrical synapse has cytoplasmic continuity.

Note:  

Most of the synapses used for signal transmission in the central nervous system are chemical synapses.

Related Pearl: Differences between Chemical and Electrical Synapses

Property

Chemical Synapse

Electrical Synapse

Distance between pre- and post-synaptic membranes

20-40 nm

4nm

Cytoplasmic continuity between pre- and post-synaptic cells

No

Yes

Ultrastructural components

Presynaptic vesicles and active zones; post synaptic receptors

Gap junctions

Agents of transmission

Chemical transmitter

Ion current

Synaptic delay

Significant: atleast 0.3 ms, usually 1-5 ms or longer

Virtually absent

Direction of transmission

Unidirectional

Usually bidirectional
